messages: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:12): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: do you mean that the WG should create more than one tutorial?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (23:16): I don't think it's a goal of the WG to produce an official tutorial
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (23:17): it's sort of a goal of mine... I wonder if I'm abusing my position or if it's in the charter...
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (23:19): nope; doesn't seem to be in the charter.

e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (23:20): I'd be fine with things like a primer btw, but I'd love for everyone to not just copy what the W3C say and make up their own mind within the constraints given by the spec
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:21): there seem to be a decent number of people within the WG wanting to write one, though
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (23:22): I've yet to see a person to actually do it
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (23:22): actually, someone did start
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (23:22): really? what did I miss?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (23:22): but it's very basic: http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Example_simple
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:24): what is a tag?
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (23:25): once I saw a tutorial that started with a plain text file... a news article, as I recall... and showed how to add HTML markup. I like that structure
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:26): I've always liked Why's (Poignant) Guide To Ruby <http://poignantguide.net/>
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (23:42): i like why's poignant guide too
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (23:43): i was trying to write a tutorial that would satisfy the people on the list, i don't think that's possible, you just second guess everything

d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (23:45): but most of all i'd just like to be bouncing ideas off someone regarding a tutorial (if we're to have one) rather than ... well whatever the discussion on tutorials has been so far
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:48): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2007Jun/0283.html (and further on that thread) give my comments
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (23:54): i've read the thread
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (23:55): I just added two subsections to the introduction: http://dev.w3.org/cvsweb/~checkout~/html5/html4-differences/Overview.html
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (23:55): Feedback welcome
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:01): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: under 2.1 I wouldn't use an ellipsis. slightly confusing at first glance
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:01): 2.1?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:02): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: char encoding
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (00:02): re intro of html-4 differences, the "Improves markup for documents" bullet doesn't make sense to me
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:03): Improved maybe?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:03): actually, no
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:03): why doesn't it make sense?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:03): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: what context is it improving it in?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:03): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, inside <meta http-equiv>?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:03): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: yes
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:04): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, structure and such, things like <figure>, <section>, etc.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:04): <hr>
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (00:06): "Improves markup for documents" is coherent english, but as a bald claim, it adds little
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (00:06): I don't know how it relates to anything else in the diffs document
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (00:07): I think I suggested something like "specifies markup for emerging idioms"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:07): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: that isn't obvious. I can just about work that out from my knowledge of HTML 5, but someone who doesn't know the spec‚Ä¶
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:07): that's 4
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:07): it relates to the first bit of the section on new elements
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:08): I suppose I could elaborate, but bullet points are supposed to be short
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (00:08): tries to think of something concise
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:08): I have to go now, I'll look in the logs and my inbox tomorrow
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (00:09): "Captures idioms for figures and sections in standardized markup". blech
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:09): what's new specifically since last week btw is section 1.1 and 1.2
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (00:10): hmm... development model... just when i was getting comfortable with leaving status info out of the diffs document.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:16): "By the time the HTML5 specification is finished there will be two complete implementations of the specification." sounds like a prediction - it should probably be more explicit, like "The HTML5 specification will not be considered finished before there are at least two complete implementations of the specification."
